awd_titl_txt: Modernization of a Technical Welding Program to Better Serve Non-Traditional Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the national need for a highly skilled STEM technical workforce.  It aims to do so by producing highly qualified welding technicians to satisfy workforce needs in the Advanced Manufacturing Industry in Western New York.  The project focuses on the unmet need for welders and metallurgy specialists in the region, a need that is expected to increase more than 7% by 2024. This project will address this workforce need by improving an existing Associates in Applied Science in Welding Technology degree program.  Improvements include relocating the welding program from an off campus vocational training center to a modernized, on-campus facility where it will be more accessible to students. The program will combine for-credit programing with non-credit certifications to produce highly trained welding technicians who are prepared for long-term careers in welding technology. These improvements are projected to double the number of students who successfully complete the program.

The project will develop a state-of-the-art welding and metal fabrication instructional lab on campus. Through the addition of this lab, as well as modification of program hours to better fit the daytime college schedule, the program intends to double its capacity and enrollment with the expectation to serve 50 students each semester. The program will host additional classes in the evenings, on weekends, and over seasonal breaks. The project will develop partnerships with area welding companies to collaboratively design course offerings and a customized curriculum with input from an Industry Advisory Council. These efforts are designed to result in a robust program that facilitates hands-on learning experiences centered on aligning student ability with employment opportunities in the field. The project will inaugurate an annual Industry Welding Day where students will showcase their work and have an opportunity to participate in open interviews with prospective employers. This unified approach is expected to increase enrollment, retention, and graduation rates within the Welding Technology Program, and thus increase the number of highly skilled technicians eligible for placement in welding careers. To better prepare students for successful careers in welding, faculty teaching in the welding technology program will earn Certified Welding Educator and Certified Welding Inspector credentials. These certifications will better prepare the faculty to educate students and evaluate their work. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts of this project were designed to be directly addressed by its Objectives and Expected Outcomes with an overall effort to eliminate many of the barriers to success in Advanced Manufacturing fields. This project focused on the Welding, AAS degree program at Niagara County Community College (NCCC). As detailed in the Annual Evaluation Report (AER) completed by the external evaluator, NCCC either achieved or made significant progress across each of the project’s six objectives.

Objectives of the grant included improvements to the infrastructure, size, and scope of the welding facility; improvements to teaching methodologies and student learning outcomes; increase in student technical skill attainment; increase in enrollment; increase in student retention; and an increase in enrollment of non-traditional students. Despite the challenges presented by the COVID-19 pandemic necessitating an extension to a fourth year, the project was largely successful in achieving five of six objectives, with the enrollment objective noting progress made.  As the program is now officially on-campus with a brand-new facility made possible through NSF investment, enrollment figures are expected to grow exponentially in the coming years. The continued development of this project has led to growth in the diversity of enrollment, particularly among Native American and female students. As of the close of this project, NCCC has become the AWS Niagara Frontier Chapter host site and an accredited testing facility, offering access to Advanced Manufacturing training for students in a variety of fields and skill levels.

While the number of participants was negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, the project was able to provide a long-term solution to gaps between anticipated job availabilities and qualified candidates in these fields. NCCC is in the process of applying for a second, NSF ATE grant which will build upon these strategies and expand them into additional Advanced Manufacturing programs as part of a phase two. This will expand the breadth of the project impact to additional high-demand programs including Mechanical Technology: Mechanical Design, Industrial Process Technology, and CNC Machining.

Activities of the project included Equipment Acquisition, Course Load Reduction for Faculty Members, Faculty Professional Development, Partnership Development, and Articulation Agreements. This resulted in the purchase of state-of-the-art equipment, individualized attention and a recruitment plan focused on underrepresented populations of students, credentialing attainment by program faculty, an Industry Advisory Council comprised of regional employers, and a new articulation agreement formalized with a local four-year institution.


Last Modified: 08/28/2024
Modified by: Mark D Voisinet
